description:
Cynara cardunculus var. scolymus, commonly known as the artichoke, is a cultivated variety of the wild cardoon plant (Cynara cardunculus). It is a perennial, thistle-like plant that belongs to the Asteraceae family.

The artichoke is characterized by its large, fleshy, and edible flower buds, which are harvested before they bloom fully. The plant produces a basal rosette of large, green, deeply lobed leaves, and its stems can reach up to 1.5 meters in height.

Artichokes are native to the Mediterranean region and have been cultivated for centuries, primarily for their culinary and medicinal properties. The edible portions of the plant, including the heart and the fleshy leaf bases, are rich in antioxidants, dietary fiber, and various vitamins and minerals.

Artichokes are widely grown and consumed around the world, and they are considered a delicacy in many cuisines. They are commonly prepared by boiling, steaming, or grilling, and can be served as a side dish or as a main ingredient in various recipes.
